rest.sentence: Wide-bandgap perovskite is considered an ideal absorber for the top component cell of a tandem configuration, in addition to having proven advantageous for indoor light conversion and semitransparent solar cells
In this work, we demonstrate an ambient aging process that appears to further raise the performance of wide-bandgap perovskite solar cells
Systematic study shows that that secondary recrystallization arises during the aging process
The defect density is further attenuated by air passivation and the self-healing effect induced by halogen redistribution
As such, the nonradiative recombination in the perovskite films is suppressed, and the carrier lifetime is prolonged during the ambient aging

The champion wide-bandgap  perovskite solar cell delivered a power-conversion efficiency as high as 20.12%, coupled with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.27 V, which is among the highest values reported for this type of wide-bandgap solar cells

This work reveals the impact of the air aging process on the properties of perovskite films from various aspects and demonstrates a scalable post-treatment strategy capable of producing state-of-the-art semiconducting films.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image

Organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites have been a rising disrupter in the photovoltaic community due to their low-temperature solution processability, high absorption coefficient, long carrier-diffusion length, and tunable direct bandgap
To date, single-junction perovskite solar cells  have reached a certified power-conversion efficiency  of 25.7%,  on par with crystalline silicon solar cells

The outstanding optoelectronic characteristics have provoked the pursuit of constructing tandem solar cells to break through the Shockley-Queisser limit ,  and further increase the PCE of current solar cells
So far, the tandem solar cells utilizing combinations of perovskite/silicon, perovskite/GaAs, and perovskite/ perovskite have achieved maximum PCEs of 31.3%,  25.2%  and 26.4%,  respectively
Note that one of the most dominant contributions to these wonderful records is the rapid advancement of wide-bandgap  perovskites  as a peculiar counterpart of typical-bandgap  perovskites  ,
Also, the flourishing WBG perovskites are also responsible for the swift development of semitransparent solar cells and dim-light conversion devices , .
The quality of WBG perovskites is promoted by learning from the optimization methodology of TBG perovskites ,

A diverse range of optimization strategies mainly incorporating mixed cation engineering, additive engineering, interface engineering and solvent engineering have been utilized with the aim of enhancing the PCE and long-term stability of WBG PSCs
Taking the 1.73-eV perovskite as an example, the corresponding PSCs have achieved a maximum PCE of 20.2% in 2021, as declared by Yang et al

Nevertheless, researchers are still struggling to overcome the challenges originating from high defect density, as it can induce ion migration, phase segregation and environmental instability in WBG perovskites ,
In particular, although the open-circuit voltage  loss in WBG PSCs has been dramatically suppressed in recent years, and the VOC “plateau” at ca
1.2 V proposed by Jen et al
in 2018 has been shifted to ca
1.3 V, for the 1.70–1.75 eV perovskites, the PCEs only witnessed trivial increment due to compromised short-circuit current density  and fill factor .

In addition to the established strategies above, a wide number of studies concerning perovskites also showed that the optoelectronic properties/performance can be further improved evidently upon exposing the perovskite films/devices to environmental gases for a few days ,
Such improvement is generally associated with aging environments , ion compositions in perovskites, device configurations  and charge transport material systems

A gas-induced defect-passivation effect has been proposed that holds the function of improving the quality of perovskite crystal, suppressing the perovskite phase separation, optimizing the band alignment, etc., thus enhancing the performance of perovskite-containing devices

noticed early on that the surface recombination rate in methylammonium lead tribromide  single crystals can be fully and reversibly controlled by exposing it to air, oxygen or moisture, indicating that the physisorption of oxygen or water molecules can passivate the surface defects Fang et al
observed a steady increment in the PCE during the initial period of storage and assigned it to the lessened charge trap density in the bulk of perovskite films Huang et al

enhanced the PCE and stability of CsPbI2Br PSCs by annealing the perovskite films in air and revealed that oxygen molecules adsorbed on CsPbI2Br could dissociate into oxygen atoms during the annealing processHu et al
The oxygen atoms interact with perovskite more effectively than oxygen molecules at halogen vacancies, leading to a better passivation effect
Moreover, recrystallization behavior was also observed during storage in the dark

declared that the tiny grains in perovskite films aggregate spontaneously, thus lessening the grain boundaries and defect states in perovskites, and as a result, the PCE and hysteresis of PSCs were improvedRoose et al
In addition to the enhancement of the perovskites, charge transport layers also play a vital role in the storage-induced PCE enhancement
For instance, the conductivity of Spiro-OMeTAD and its band alignment with perovskites would be improved after the aging process due to the ease of oxidation and redistribution of dopants ,

Although numerous studies have demonstrated that the effect of storage on initial cell performance improvement is associated with both the perovskites and charge transport materials,  the underlying mechanism remains insufficiently investigated in depth, let alone applying it to the performance improvement of WBG PSCs.
In this work, we demonstrated an air-aging process  to significantly improve the performance of PSCs employing Cs0.15FA0.79MA0.06Pb3 WBG perovskite
Numerous characterizations were performed to explore the underlying mechanism behind the AAP-induced PCE increment
After AAP for 72 h, we validate that the crystallinity of the perovskite films intensified, driven by the spontaneous relaxation of lattice stress
In the meantime, the defects in the perovskite film are passivated due to the oxygen absorption and halogen redistribution/diffusion
In addition, we disclose that the positive effect of AAP on initial cell performance also benefited from the temporal changes of HTM
As such, the average PCE is increased from 17.45 ± 0.79% to 18.78 ± 0.80%, and the champion device with AAP displays PCE as high as 20.12%, contributed to by the high VOC of 1.27 V
These results provide some novel ideas for subsequent processing that can pave the way for improving the PCE of freshly prepared WBG-PSCs , .

1a shows cross-sectional scanning electron microscope  image of a PSC with the n-i-p structure of FTO/TiO2/perovskite/Spiro-OMeTAD/Au, that employs a triple-cation perovskite Cs0.15FA0.79MA0.06Pb3 with a WBG of 1.74 eV Fig
The decent perovskite films devoid of transverse grain boundaries have the thickness of ca
AAP was carried out by storing the perovskite films or fresh integral devices in dry air  at room temperature for 72 h690 nm
All

In summary, we demonstrated that AAP is an effective strategy that can further raise the PCE of WBG PSCs, whereby a champion PCE of 20.12% with an outstanding VOC of 1.27 V was obtained in the AAP-PSCs
In addition, a 4-T, all-perovskite, tandem solar cell was constructed and delivered a PCE of 21.45%
The enhanced PCE is related to the reduced defect density in the devices, which can be further attributed to the recrystallization process induced by stress relaxation, the halogen redistribution
Yang Yang: Investigation, Software, Data curation, Writing – original draft preparation
Lu Liu: Investigation, Software, Formal analysis, Data curation, Writing – review & editing

Shuai Zhao: Software, Methodology
Zhen Chang: Data curation

This work was supported by the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences , the National Nature Science Foundation of China , the Innovation Fund Project of Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics , the Cooperation Foundation of Dalian National Laboratory For Clean Energy of the Chinese Academy of Sciences , the National Key R&D Program of China , the

The heterointerfaces of charge-selective contacts are crucial in determining efficiency and stability of perovskite optoelectronic devices, where the fundamental knowledge of the buried heterointerface between perovskite and bottom charge transport layer is less well understood compared to the top interface

Herein, we systematically investigate the energetics at the perovskite/SnO2 buried heterointerface for an n-i-p perovskite solar cell  and the perovskite/PEDOT:PSS buried heterointerface for a p-i-n one, respectively

In contrast to previous cognitions, we discover a perovskite transition phase at the buried interface region that originates from the chemical bonding interaction with the bottom charge transport layer
The transition phase causes an energy level barrier and induces defects, impeding charge transport across the heterointerface
These detrimental effects trigger significant nonradiative recombination and limit the attainable device photovoltage
We then develop the energetic models that describe such buried heterointerfaces
Moreover, we further test the proposed model-derived mechanisms via inserting a thin polyvinyl alcohol layer into the buried heterointerfaces of the devices

We demonstrate that chemical interactions and formation of the perovskite transition phase at the buried heterointerface thereby are fully restrained, leading to a diminished electron extraction barrier and improved charge transport
As a result, significant increases in open-circuit voltage and fill factor of the devices are achieved
These results will help guide future efforts on developing suitable buried heterointerfaces for superior performance of perovskite optoelectronics.
Although perovskite solar cells  have achieved significant success, there are still some barriers to their commercialization, such as poor stability and unsatisfactory power conversion efficiency
Here, we report low-dimensionality engineering of perovskites using mercaptoethylammonium iodide
Two-dimensional  perovskite materials can simultaneously passivate the interface defects of the perovskite film and enhance carrier extraction
The PCE of the device increased from 20.85% for the control device to a resultant of 22.41% for the target device
Meanwhile, device stability was ameliorated after MEMI modification, and the stability of unencapsulated target devices decreased by 7.5% after aging in the dark air condition for 300 h
Finally, the notorious lead leakage was significantly suppressed
This work guides to create efficient and stable environmentally friendly PSCs through low-dimensional engineering.

Owing to their low cost, high efficiency, property tunability, and flexibility, metal halide perovskites  show great promise in next-generation optoelectronics, including perovskite-based solar cells, photodetectors, and light-emitting diodes

However, the long-term stability of these perovskite-based optoelectronic devices  is far from satisfactory, and their poor stability greatly hinders their future commercialization in real-world applications
Essentially speaking, the performance loss of PODs is due to the structural change of the core MHP layer either physically or chemically
Fortunately, these physicochemical changes are found to be reversible under controlled conditions, which offers a critical opportunity to address the long-term stability problem of PODs
In this review, we comprehensively summarize the current understanding of performance loss and the corresponding advanced healing strategies for PODs

First, four typical pathways of MHP aging that cause the performance loss of PODs are discussed, including phase transitions, phase segregation, photoactivated trap states, and structural decomposition of MHPs
Then, state-of-the-art strategies for promoting the healing of MHPs and the performance recovery of PODs are introduced
Finally, the current challenges and future prospects in this exciting research direction are discussed
This review highlights the significance of developing healable PODs, which is expected to enhance the robustness of PODs and promote their large-scale industrialization in the near future.

Flexible perovskite solar cells are new energy devices with a promising future due to their numerous advantages, such as high defect tolerance, strong solar absorption and low non-radiative carrier recombination rates
However, their operational stability is still an ongoing challenge during upgrading, and their inferior moisture corrosion resistance is still a major issue for better performances

Thin-film encapsulation could effectively enhance the operational stability of perovskite solar cells but obtaining encapsulation films with excellent barrier performance always come at the expense of poor flexibility
Therefore, the development of novel encapsulation materials with both barrier performance and flexibility is urgent for the compatibility of flexible applications

In this work, "Plasma-Enhanced Molecular Layer Deposition" was used for the first time to prepare a highly cross-linked, densified flexible encapsulation material AlOC at 40 ℃ to break through the traditional technology
The resulting encapsulation material can be applied to flexible perovskite solar cells as a barrier film without any damage

The as-obtained encapsulation film exhibited a water vapor transmittance rate of 1.44 × 10−5 g m−2 day−1 and preserved 95 % of its initial barrier performance after 10,000 bends with a 3 mm bend radius
Such performance was the best among the reported thin-film encapsulation layers of flexible perovskite solar cells.
Inorganic perovskites are receiving growing attention due to good thermal stability and fast-improving photovoltaic performance
However, most of the high-efficiency inorganic perovskite solar cells  were fabricated in inert atmosphere
Herein, we report an additive-assisted airflow drying  method to make mixed-halide inorganic perovskite films in ambient air
The nucleation and crystal growth during film formation are controlled by using airflow dying and lead acetate trihydrate additive, producing pinhole-free film with low defect density
Consequently, efficiency of CsPbI2.25Br0.75 PSCs is improved to 18.49%, which is the highest for wide-bandgap  inorganic PSCs
An efficiency of 17.08% is achieved for PSCs made under moderate relative humidity
Moreover, PCEs of 17.39% and 11.54% are achieved for CsPbI2Br and CsPbIBr2 PSCs, respectively, which are among the best PCEs for CsPbI2Br and CsPbIBr2 PSCs
This work provides a convenient and efficient method to make efficient inorganic PSCs in ambient air.
The exceptional photovoltaic properties of Sn-based perovskite solar cells  have caught the interest of researchers as a potential candidate for the development of non-toxic PSCs
Nevertheless, the Sn–PSCs still face some critical drawbacks, such as the easier oxidation of Sn2+ to Sn4+ and the moisture permeation, which reduce their stability and power conversion efficiency
In this work, to tackle these limitations, we added a Lewis base additive formamidinesulfinic acid  to the perovskite precursor solution
The FASO2H Lewis base additive could successfully reduce the oxidation of Sn2+/Sn4+ by 32%, improved the crystallinity and decreased the lattice strain by 66% in the respective films
As a result, the charge carrier recombination minimized and the FASnI3-FASO2H  based PSCs produced a PCE of 7.44%
The FASO2H additive also offers superior moisture protection for Sn–PSCs thanks to its hydrophobic sulfinic acid group
Notably, the Sn–PSCs exhibit a high light soaking stability by maintaining 90% of the initial PCE up to 450 h when tested under maximum power point tracking conditions.
Yang and LY
Liu equally contribute to this work.
